Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: No 12

Consulate General of the United States.
Monrovia, Liberia, May 1st 1888.
Mr B. Y. Payne to the Hon., Secretary of State
Subject:
Receipt of Despatch No 18 Dipo' Series, and compensation
Sir

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your No 18 Diplomatic Series of the 22nd utl., with enclosure of form of Account and Draft, informing me that Mr. Charles H. J. Taylor has resigned the position of United States Minister to Liberia, and his agreement agreement
Hon., T. F. Bayard
Secretary of State
&c &c &c
agreement with me, as to my compensation during his leave of absence has expired: also informing me that the Department desires me to remain in charge of the archives of the Legation and Consulate General, pending the arrival of a successor to Mr Taylor, stating further that I shall receive the same compensation for service viz $300. per annum, the amount allowed me by Mr Taylor.
I thank you, for the confidence reposed in me, in wishing me to remain in charge of the Legation.

For your better information, I enclose Mr. Taylor's two letters to me, in which he offered me me
me the position with compensation at the rate of $300. per annum. You are aware I contracted with Mr. Taylor for this amount, but you will see by his letter and the contract that I was already employed, and would have nothing to do, but attend the mails, and keep in safety the Archives of the Legation: Since, a Bond of $3000. has been required of me, which I have forwarded to the Department.

I consented to receive the compensation offered by Mr Taylor, because he would be absent but twelve (12) weeks, as I had occasion to refer you to some time ago; now that Mr Taylor's functions has ceased, and I required to give give
give the Bond required of a Vice Consul General. I cannot for the compensation offend, hence, I do not sign the Draft for services to 31st March, at Mr Taylor's rate of compensation, but retain it, and await your advice, as I am quite satisfied you can see my position. I have in many instance lost in my other avocation to do justice and hence to the trust I have.

I do not object to receiving compensation at the rate contracted with Mr. Taylor for the terms of his incumbency, therefore I have this day drawn my Draft No 1 on the Secretary of State for services according to the Contract Contract
Contract from October 3rd 1887 (The date of Mr Taylor's departure) to the 12th January 1888 when his official function, and my contract with him ceased.
I enclose account , as per copy for form, transmitted to me.

Having forwarded my Bond to the Department, and reported, I consider myself directly responsible to the Government of the United States, and to it will I expect compensation for service from January 12th 1888.
I have the honor to be Sir, Your obedient Servant
Beverly Y. Payne
Enclosures, Mr Taylor to Mr Payne Sec'y Barclay,, ,, Taylor Account Compensation
Monrovia Liberia Sept 16th 1887
Capt. Beverly Y. Payne, oc.. oc.. oc.. Monrovia Liberia.,

Sir: Without any application having been filed by you, in the U.S. Legation for any position within my gift. I do hereby say to you that if you feel disposed to take charge of the Legation in my absence, until my return to the country, I will immediately upon my return nominate you for the position of U.S. Vice Consul Gen'l for the Republic of Liberia. I would nominate you now, only I have declared to the Department at Washington, my intention of allowing the post of Vice Consul Gen'l to remain vacant, until the embarrassing situation of the late Vice Consul Gen'l here, shall have been explained, and passed on. You will please decide in reference to this matter on or before the 22nd inst. if you consent to accept the I will enter into a contract to pay you at the rate of $300 per annum, for the time I am absent. In
Monrovia Liberia Sept 19th 1887
Hon Beverly Y. Payne.

Sir: I am in receipt of your favor, of even date herewith, accepting the Position of Acting Vice Consul General, for the United States. Please find enclosued a "blank contract" which you will greatly oblige me to make duplicate (2) copies of. Return th them, (3) three copies to me. I will sign them with you, giving into your possession one copy, filing with the Department of State in Washington, one; and retaining one copy myself. The matter of your being from the date of my departure U.S. acting Vice Consul General is no longer a secret. You are at liberty to make statement of the fact, to anyone you please at any time in the future where you may feel disposed, after your regular hours in the store, you may call on me when I will proceed to give you such intstructions as I may think proper for you to know, in order to insure a correct discharge of duty. I can assure you, that only two things moved one to appoint you. First, your conduct as an upright young man, and the facct that you hold no civil office in the Republic. I predict, for you a "brilliant future" if you maintain through life, your present course.
I am sir, your obedient servant.
Chas. H. J. Taylor
Department of State.
Monrovia September 27th 1887 Liberia, W. C. A.
Hon: C. H. J. Taylor U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General U.S. Legation Monrovia.

Sir, I am in receipt of your communication of the 26th inst, in which you infrom med that you "shall take your departure for America, via England or Hamburg, by the next vessel or Steamer thither bound:" and further informing me that "during my (your) absence, I (you) shall be pleased to have you consider Mr Beverly Y. Payne as in charge of the United States Consulate General at this place," and that Mr. Payne "will act in the capacity and quality of U.S. Acting Vice Consul General."

In reply permit me Sir, to advise you of the consent of this Government to your proposed arrangement with reference to Mr B. Y. Payne's exercising the function of U.S. Acting Vice Consul General during your absence, and thanking you for your kind offer of services to the Government.
I have the honor to be Sir Your obedient Servant
E. J. Barclay
